properties.name: Aldrich's Market
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2    940 Lawrence St, Port Townsend, WAThis market is a gem nestled into Upper Town. Carrying local and organic produce, specialty food items, and natural meat without antibiotics, this is a great place to assemble a healthy picnic. The orginal market was built in 1895, but tragically a fire burned the historic building to the ground in 2003. The new building captures the turn of the century aura quite well.

properties.name: Alexander's Castle
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  241 Battery Way, Port Townsend, WAA strange hybrid of house and castle, this brick building stands forlorn on the hill overlooking the water in the Fort Worden park complex. A lovestruck gentleman built this as a home for his girl, but by the time he finished construction, she had left him for another. The house seems to know this, and stands waiting in sorrow for it\'s love to return. One of our favorite finds in Port Townsend.

properties.name: American Camp - Obscure History Lesson
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2    2982 Cattle Point Road, Friday Harbor, WACrazy fact: The United States almost went to war with Britain over a dead pig! American Camp is one of two sections of the San Juan National Park. We biked to this little known park and discovered an obscure piece of American history. Back in 1859, an American shot a British pig eating in his garden. The British threatened the Americans and pretty soon both sides were calling in reinforcements, until saner officers diffused the situation. Today you can wander the meadows of the site were the American troops were stationed. The vistas of the sea are especially breathtaking on clear days when the wildflowers are in bloom. Stop into the visitor center for a helpful map of the island and of the two camps, especially important if you are biking.

properties.name: Anchorage
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 Anchorage

properties.name: Authentic Chinatown
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2    100 E. Pender Street, Vancouver, BCA living, breathing Chinatown in the heart of Vancouver. As an authentic neighborhood, this Chinatown is grittier than many Chinatowns in the West that have become more tourist-oriented. As a result, it\'s a great place to experience a glimpse into daily life. Check out the markets, especially the colorful night market, stroll the gardens, and peek into historic areas like Shanghai Alley. Be forewarned, the crime and drug-ridden neighborhood of Downtown Eastside is only a couple blocks away, so stay alert. If you stumble into this area, walk with purpose back into Chinatown. Better yet, set up a self-guided walking tour plan ahead of time that avoids this section and stick to it.

properties.name: Barb's Fish and Chips
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  310 Erie Street, Victoria, BCThis is a fantastic little chippie in Fisherman\'s Wharf. We had an inexpensive and tasty dinner on the water surrounded by houseboats before strolling the waterfront at sunset. Sit down at a picnic table and enjoy the atmosphere! This place is also a hit with locals.

properties.name: Barclay Square
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  Barclay Square, Vancouver, BCThis quiet square is a relaxing place to escape the summer crowds and rest your feet from pounding the pavement. The square is shaded by a huge canopy of trees, and is bordered by historic Victorian mansions. Bring a cup of coffee and savor the genteel life of Vancouver\'s West End.

properties.name: Beacon Hill Park
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 Beacon Hill, Victoria, BCI\'m sure this is a perfectly gorgeous park, but my slightly deranged husband dragged me here after dark, determined to see this park that was recommended by a local despite our lack of time. My overall impression - excellent place to look at a full moon. Eerie and very Wuthering Heights! There are also numerous homeless people who sleep here at night. While I never felt threatened, stick to visiting during the day!

properties.name: Best Western Carlton Plaza
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 642 Johnson Street, Victoria, BCWe stayed here on our honeymoon. While nothing special, it\'s convienent to the Inner Harbour, close to restaurants, and offers the typical range of amenities at big city Best Westerns. It\'s institutional feeling, not particularly romantic or cozy, and lacking character. If you\'re looking to save some money and still be near all the action, this is a decent choice.

properties.name: Best Western Downtown Vancouver
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 718 Drake Street, Vancouver, BCThis chain hotel is better than most in the Best Western family, with a helpful and friendly staff and sparkling rooms. We were upgraded to a corner room with sweeping views of the city. While the decor is typical bland hotel, the location is great for the cost - making this a great value. Only a short walk from the water, local beaches, and restaurants. Just be aware that the slightly gritty Granville Street is a couple blocks away. Expect to pay 20-150 a night.

properties.name: Breath-taking Mt. Consitution
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   Moran State Park, WAAwe-inspiring, I could write a host of adjectives and never do the views from the top of Mt. Constitution justice. Just go. This is the don\'t-miss attraction of the San Juan Islands. Drive up to the top (only the insane would bike the steep and winding roads) and just breathe in the 360 degree views as far as the eye can see. Once you\'ve drunk your fill, head elsewhere inside Moran State Park to hike the trails.

properties.name: Brewed Awakenings
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 107 E. College Avenue, Appleton, WIThis funky little coffeeshop is a breath of fresh air from the neighboring chain Starbucks. A crowd of students and young professionals frequent this coffeeshop. I love the fresh and strong brews of the days, as well as the tempting nibbles in the display case, such as the giant muffins. They sell whole beans and are an environmentally-conscious business, providing shade-grown coffee.

properties.name: British Camp - Obscure History Lesson Part 2
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2    3140 W Valley Rd, San JuanIf you visit American Camp, be sure to visit this section of the San Juan National Park, situated on secluded Garrison Bay. Wander around the rebuilt guardhouse and the formal English garden. There is also a graveyard a steep hike up into the trees. The lack of people gives this camp a spooky feeling, even in broad daylight.

properties.name: Butchart Gardens - Overcrowded, but Beautiful
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   800 Benvenuto Ave, Brentwood Bay, BCWhile packed with swarms of pushy tourists and tour buses, and overrated by all the guidebooks and tourist propaganda, the Butchart Gardens are still interesting and beautiful to wander. If you have an interest in photography or gardening, then this is a must-see. I lost my husband to his camera for 3 hours. While I longed for a romantic walk together through the lush rose arbors and tranquil Japanese garden, his camera was permanently afixed to his face. To avoid the hassle of renting a car and dealing with parking, take the Gray Line bus shuttle from Victoria\'s bus station, near the Empress Hotel. Also pack your nerves - the hordes of older tourists blocking the paths and views will take some of the magic away from your experience. Avoid weekends!

properties.name: Canada Place - Overrated
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2     800 Canada Pl, Vancouver, BCWhile a gorgeous place to stroll and take photos of the mountains across the inlet on a sunny day, this giant entertainment, convention, and business complex is really a glorified pier full of docking cruise ships. Spend no more than half an hour here people-watching, and pop into the excellent TI. Unless you\'re catching a film at the I-MAX theater, move on to more authentic parts of the city. This is Vancouver\'s #1 tourist trap.

properties.name: Cattle Point - Sunset Views
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  2900 Scenic Drive, Victoria, BCThis is the best place in town to watch the sunset! Windy and wild Cattle Point overlooks Willow Bay and the beach, and while the wind makes it chilly, that just encourages some cuddling with your honey!

properties.name: Chinatown
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   551 Fisgard Street, Victoria, BCAs a tiny neighborhood encompassing just a couple blocks, Victoria\'s historic Chinatown is easy to browse in an hour. The majority of the historic buildings line Fisgard Street. Duck into quirky Fan Tan Alley, supposedly the world\'s narrowest street. Once the home of opium dens and gambling parlors, the alley now houses shops. I have seen more lived in and authentic Chinatowns elsewhere, but the historic buildings here are worth a look.

properties.name: Christmas 365 Days a Year!
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  1022 Government Street, Victoria, BCIn a holiday mood? This shop, the Spirit of Christmas, is a feast for the eyes. Anything to do with Christmas, you\'ll find here, from the collectible village sets to unique handcrafted ornaments. Just make sure you\'re not one of those who grinch about Christmas coming earlier every year before you step inside!

properties.name: Copper Rock - My Favorite Coffeeshop
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 210 W. College Avenue, Appleton, WIOf all the locally-owned coffeeshops in Appleton, I keep coming back to Copper Rock for their friendly service, freshly roasted brew and delicate specialty mochas and lattes. The atmosphere is convivial - people meet here with friends to chat, catch a bite to eat, and study. The decor is modern, with a touch of rustic flair from the exposed brick wall and hammered tin ceiling. The place is full of people of all ages, from college students to businessmen on their lunch breaks. They serve a wide range of food, from soups to sandwiches to salads, all freshly made. The food may not be anything to rave about, but it\'s filling and satisfying. The Copper Rock also hosts live music on the weekends. Try to avoid the lunch rush, when the place is a zoo. If you\'re looking for a quiet place to study, try mid-morning or mid-afternoon.

properties.name: Crowded and Sun-tanned English Beach
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   1900 Beach Avenue, Vancouver, BCOn a hot, sunny summer day, it seems every local discovers this one beach. It is CROWDED and the place to see and be seen in an otherwise unpretentious city. Expect to fight over space to lay out a blanket in the summer. There\'s a great playground slide for the kids. A short walk away find Denman Street and hot dog stands.

properties.name: Current Residence - Appleton, Wisconsin
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 Appleton, WisconsinAppleton is a mid-size city in NE Wisconsin. When I first ended up here for college, I wasn\'t a huge fan of the city, but I met and married a local boy, and I\'ve come to discover Appleton\'s good side. There\'s a pleasant downtown with a performing arts center, many restaurants to sample, a highly-ranked liberal arts college, and a growing number of atmospheric coffee shops.

properties.name: Delectable Roger's Chocolates
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   913 Government Street, Victoria, BCPure heaven. Step inside to inhale the scent of all things chocolate. Try the melt-in-your-mouth samples. And bring a couple bars of chocolate home to eat later. We bought the orange chocolate bar and when we ate it, we were immediately transported back to our honeymoon. There\'s another store in Oak Bay with less foot traffic and friendlier staff.

properties.name: Dismal Starbucks
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 5 College Avenue, Appleton, WII tend to dislike mega-chains, especially when it comes to coffee, but this Starbucks has one of the worst atmospheres I\'ve seen. Growing up in Portland, I appreciate the locally-run neighborhood coffee shop, with its unique character. This Starbucks is bland - no real decor theme and a lack of comfortable seating. The baristas are friendly enough, but the coffee tastes burnt, and I happen to adore strong coffee. (I know this is a common complaint, and I\'ve experienced this at every Starbucks I\'ve been to - it has to be the Starbucks roasting process). At least they kept the historic storefront in tact so it blends into downtown Appleton. With the wealth of other local coffee options just steps away, I would avoid Starbucks at all costs. FYI: Address is actually 101 E. College, but it wasn\'t showing up in the right location on the map.

properties.name: Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  578 Carrall St, Vancouver, BCWe spent all afternoon at the annual gay pride parade, so by the time we got to Chinatown, most sites were closed, including this classical Chinese garden. Like furtive little children, we peaked through the gate and got a glimpse of a lush and balanced world. Definately check this garden out, just pay better attention to the time than we did!

properties.name: Eccentric Craigdarroch Castle
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   1050 Joan Crescent, Victoria, BCA quirky and fascinating mansion built by a Canadian robber baron in the 1880s. The house is enormous, and the rooms are exquisite and well-preserved. Anyone with a fascination for the Victorian era or antiques will be entertained. The wood work blew me away and the attic ballroom and tower room are especially thrilling. AVOID the day cruise ship groups flood the mansion. When we were there in 2006, that was Thursdays - call ahead to be sure. We ended up being pushed and elbowed by the crowds, which spoils the magic. According to the museum staff, other days you might have the place to yourself!

properties.name: Empress Hotel
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2    721 Government Street, Victoria, BCThe Fairmont Empress is beautiful and romantic to look at from the outside. The walls are dripping in ivy and the location is perfect, right along the harbor. However, staying here is a less than romantic experience. I\'ve heard the Signature rooms and suites are roomy and worth the high price tag, but as a lowly budget traveler in 1998, we had the basic double, which was almost like a standard Motel 6 room. Step into the Empress lobby to soak up the history, try the afternoon tea, or wander their garden, but you\'ll find nicer places to sleep for a whole lot less. If you do stay here, make sure to try the tiny swimming pool in the basement. It\'s claustrophobic, but has a very turn of the century feeling of elegance to it. Expect to pay between 50 to 00 a night.

properties.name: False Bay - Photo Op
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 1954 False Bay DriveWe biked off the main roads on San Juan Island and discovered this quiet bay. Take a moment to gaze out over the glistening sea and smell the wildflowers. When the tide is out, do not walk out on the bay - the exposed mud does not look particularily safe and you may become stuck.

properties.name: Farmer's Market
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2    Tyler Street and Lawrence Street, Port Townsend, WAWe stumbled randomly over this delightful little farmers market while on our honeymoon. The market runs all summer every Saturday, and while small, it\'s a joy to chat with the sellers and sample some of the jams and honeys. Consider assembling a picnic lunch from the produce and treats for sale.

properties.name: Fins Coastal Cuisine
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 1019 Water Street, Port Townsend, WAA fine dining seafood experience on the waterfront. Fins has a relaxed, but modern vibe, with gorgeous views of the water. We ate here on our honeymoon, and the salmon was just right - moist, easily flaked, subtle flavors. My only complaint is that we had to wait over 45 minutes to be seated, even with a reservation! Luckily, the food was worth it. Expect to pay 0-30 per person, so this is definately a splurge.

properties.name: Floatplane Docks - Missed Opportunity!
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   950 Wharf Street, Victoria, BCAs an airplane enthusiast, I am kicking myself for not getting up early enough to check out the Blackfish Cafe for the "breakfast show" - floatplanes taking off and landing. If you want a glimpse into Victoria\'s maritime lifeblood, drag yourself out of bed to catch the action. This is at the top of my list for my next visit.

properties.name: Fort Worden State Park
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2     Fort Worden, WAWe spent a full day here exploring the decommissioned fort that was once part of the coastal defense system. The movie An Officer and A Gentleman was filmed here, so everything feels eerily familar! We toured the Commanding Officer\'s House, strolled along the beaches, and ducked into the spooky abandoned gun emplacements. Kids love running around the place with a flashlight, even "big kids" like us! There are also a youth hostel and camping sites here for all you budget-minded folks.

properties.name: Fox Cities Performing Arts Center
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   400 W. College Avenue, Appleton, WII work here, so I am biased, but the Fox Cities PAC is the best thing about Appleton. There is always something going on here, from Broadway musicals to ballets to education shows for the schools. The PAC hosts three different seasons: the Fox Valley Symphony, Broadway Across America, and the PAC\'s own Arts Alive series, which includes comedy, dance, and musical groups from around the world. Some recent performances include Broadway musicals The Lion King, Wicked and Avenue Q; Garrison Keillior\'s A Prairie Home Companion, the Boston Pops, the Soweto Gospel Choir, and Mannheim Steamroller.

properties.name: Gastown
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2     Gastown, Vancouver, BCVancouver\'s #1 Tourist Trap. Don\'t let this keep you away, just temper your expectations. A couple hours is more than enough to stroll the cobblestone streets and peek into the mix of shops from tacky souvenirs to First Nations artwork. The steam clock will mesmerize youngsters - just don\'t let the cat out of the bag about how the clock really works (not actually by steam - sorry!). Keep in mind that shops start closing around 4pm. Enjoy a decent meal and soak up the Victorian ambience. Then skidaddle this tourist trap to see the authentic Vancouver.

properties.name: Granville Island - Vancouver's Artistic Center
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2      Granville Island, Vancouver, BCDitch the car and take a sea bus to this small island in the heart of Vancouver. You\'ll spend a pleasant afternoon browsing the traffic-free artists\' community and public market. Assemble a picnic in the market and snag bench space on the water while you munch. Something\'s always going on here. While we were there, we danced to a salsa band by the market, browsed artisans\' workshops, and stumbled across a sidewalk chalk festival dsplaying a vast array of local talent. This is one of Vancouver\'s best free sights.

properties.name: Hamburger Mary's Diner
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 1202 Davie Street, Vancouver, BCIf you\'ve tired of Vancouver\'s world-class restaurant scene and just want a good ol\' hearty burger, come to Hamburger Mary\'s. The food is comforting, in that high carb, high grease grand tradition of diners everywhere. I got a classic burger and shake dinner, and let full and satisfied. A great place for the kids. Just don\'t expect phenomenal service - it\'s a tad slow. Expect to pay -12 a person.

properties.name: Hill's Native Art
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  1008 Government Street, Victoria, BCOf all of Victoria\'s shops, this is a must-see, even if it\'s just to droll over the beautiful craftsmanship of modern-day native artists. Being part Native American myself, I appreciate how tastefully the shop is run and presented. This is top-quality and authentic art from the First Peoples of Canada, and the staff know what they are talking about. While I wasn/t able to afford anything, I\'m saving for a bentwood box for the next time I\'m in town!

properties.name: Historic but Empty Market Square
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  530 Johnson Street, Victoria, BCMarket Square as a historic landmark is interesting - a central courtyard surrounded on all sides by brick buildings that were once shipping businesses and warehouses. It is now a shopping complex, but surprisingly sparse on shops! We ducked into a couple of toy and trinket shops, but didn\'t find much else of interest. Peak in and enjoy the ghostly 1800s atmosphere, but don\'t expect to be dazzled by the shopping.

properties.name: Hotel Deluxe
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 729 Sw 15th Ave, Portland, ORWe stayed here on our wedding night right after their remodel from the old Hotel Mallory, Located downtown just steps away from the light rail. The hotel follows a modern and classic Hollywood theme that made us feel glamorous. The beds are super soft, the robes plush, and the hotel sent up complimentary champagne and strawberries. Our only complaint (and it\'s minor) is that they forgot the corkscrew, and when we asked for one, we waited 45 mins after the front desk said they would send one right up. My husband finally went down to get one from the friendly bartender. Kudos to management for making amends by giving us a free breakfast in their elegant restaurant.

properties.name: Hudson's Bay Company
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  600 Fort Street, Victoria, BCI usually avoid big department stores when I\'m traveling, but the HBC is an historic landmark in the Pacific Northwest. This is Canada\'s (and the Northwest\'s) oldest department store. Don\'t spend too much time here, since it is just a modern-day store, but do consider going home with a classic wool point blanket as a souvenir. Just be forewarned - they are very expensive!

properties.name: Huhot - A Great Value!
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  3456 W. College Avenue, Appleton, WIIf you\'re looking for value and have a big appetite, this Mongolian grill is a smart choice for a meal out. You pay for an all-you-can-eat lunch or dinner, select your own ingredients and sauces, and watch the chefs cook your food on the grill. The variety of sauce combos makes the food really tasty - last time we went, my husband went back for thirds! Just beware the weekends - Huhot is popular and crowded, and the Saturday night wait in line for the grill can be frustrating when you\'re hungry! (I once waited half an hour).

properties.name: Island Bicycles
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  380 Argyle Street, Friday Harbor, WAIf you\'re in decent shape and want to bike San Juan Island, this is the place to rent a bike. They provide an emergency kit, tire pump, and helmet along with the bike. Depending on the bike you choose, rentals cost 5-70 a day. The island does not have bike trails; you will be biking on the side of the road as cars wizz past, so this may not be a smart activity for families with small children.

properties.name: Kathmandu Valley
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 Katmandu, NepalI spent a summer here in 1998 helping with a construction project at an orphanage in the Kathmandu Valley. The city is a buffet for the senses - ancient architecture, crowds of people going about their daily business, monks eating at burger joints, temples, cows wandering along the road, children playing soccer in the surrounding hills, and vibrantly decorated trucks. Outside the city, the foothills are lush and green, and a hike through the rice paddies is an important look into the agricultural lives of the people. And surrounding the valley on all sides (when the clouds clear! I was there during the monsoon season), are the Himalayas, silent and forboding sentinels.

properties.name: La Bodega Tapas
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 1277 Howe Street, Vancouver, BCThis cozy little tapas restaurant is worth seeking out. We got ourselves majorly lost on our first night in Vancouver trying to find this place, and it turned out it was a block from our hotel the entire time! An hour of walking worked up a huge appetite and we dove in to the numerous little plates and the refreshing sangria. A romantic place to dine, and the food is flavorful, fresh and adventerous. The sangria is the best I\'ve had in North America. My husband, who\'s been to Spain, raved about the food. Get a few different plates to share and sample. Make sure to reserve ahead. Expect to pay -8 a plate.

properties.name: Lawrence University - My Alma Mater
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  100 S. Union Street, Appleton, WIOnce again I\'m biased, since I graduated from here in 2004, but Lawrence University is a fantastic undergraduate liberal arts school. I have never regretted choosing to attend here. The university is divided between the college and the music conservatory. While all the students mingle, the "connies" are known for being singularly focused on their music studies. Students also tend to have a quirky side, which we jokingly referred to as "the Lawrence Difference" (which is printed on the school\'s literature). An example of this is the annual student-run Midwest Trivia Contest, broadcast every year on Wisconsin Public Radio for a weekend in January. Off-campus teams are welcome to join and teams come from all over the Midwest and beyond. Lawrence hosts a wide range of artistic and cultural events throughout the year, many of which are open to the public. These include full-scale operas and musicals, dramas, musical concerts and student recitals. Lawrence also hosts an annual Jazz Festival with a range of world-renowned jazz artists, and a convocation series which brings in a variety of experts to share their expertise, including people such as Fareed Zakaria, Lech Walsea, and Frank McCourt. Wander the beautiful collegiate campus, especially in the fall when the Main Hall Green is awash in brilliant reds and golds.

properties.name: Lime Kiln State Park
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2    Lime Kiln State ParkA great place to picnic. We stopped here during our island bike ride and found a picnic table looking out over the water. During orca whale-watching season (june to Sep) you may actually be able to see the whales from the park - keep your eyes on the water! There is also a small lighthouse that you can walk up to.

properties.name: Market Chef
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 225 A Street, Friday Harbor, WAIf you\'re looking for a healthy lunch, this is a great low-cost option. The sandwiches are big and hearty. They will also pack a picnic lunch for you, an option we tried when we embarked on a day bike trip around the island. This place may not be gourmet, but the ingredients are fresh and the service friendly.

properties.name: Museum of Anthropology
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  6393 NW Marine Drive, Vancouver, BCAs an anthropology minor in college and someone of native descent, I am endlessly FASCINATED by this museum. Tucked into a quiet corner of the UBC campus, the museum has a jam-packed array of bentwood boxes, totem poles, argillite sculptures and masks. Be forewarned that the items on display are not well labelled for the novice viewer, so plan to take one of the excellent and free guided tours. While I aimlessly wandered, my husband soaked up the information and learned a lot more than I did. There\'s also a section that\'s a working archive, where you can peruse the storage cases of thousands of objects, using the reference catalogs to find descriptions of what you\'re seeing. Be sure to wander outside to the longhouse and lonely totem poles overlooking English Bay. The highlight of the museum for me was the gorgeous "Raven and the First Men", carved by Haida artists Bill Reid. Placed in its own atrium and bathed in sunlight, truly a jaw-dropping and mystical experience. You can reach the museum by public transportation, just be sure to verify with the bus driver where to get off for the UBC campus. It\'s a pleasant 10 minute walk through campus to the museum, including a quick stroll through a rose garden.

properties.name: My Beloved Hometown
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 Portland, OregonPortland gets under your skin and buried deep within your soul. I grew up here, and while I somehow ended up halfway across the country, I always find myself coming back here. If you love coffee, books, the outdoors and hiking, biking, the green movement, the arts, and microbreweries, you\'ve come to the right place!

properties.name: Nifty Fiftys Diner
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  817 Water Street, Port Townsend, WAWe would have passed by this 1950s-style nostalgia diner, except that I spied a Green River soda on the menu! Any fan of classic soda fountains and milkshakes will want to stop in here, and kids will love the basic American grub. While nothing out-of-this-world, the food is satisfying. While you\'re eating, check out the juke box and tap your feet to Elvis Presley and Buddy Holly.

properties.name: Nine O'clock Gun - Keepin' Time
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  2000 Stanley Park Drive, Vancouver, BCThis old cannon on Brockton Point in Stanley Park still keeps time for the local fishermen. going off at 9pm to let them know it\'s time to come in for the night. If you happen to be nearby at that time, cover your ears! While the fishing industry no longer needs it, tradition wins the day, so the gun keeps on firing.

properties.name: Oak Bay Village
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   Oak Bay, Victoria, BC, CanadaA small neighborhood outside central Victoria, Oak Bay is a nice retreat from the crowds of tourists. Here many of the residents actually live, shop, and play. Strolling the main street of the village is a nice afternoon diversion, with eclectic bookshops, flower stands, tea shops, and British pubs. Make sure to converse with the shopkeepers - they are friendly and full of advice.

properties.name: Old Spaghetti Factory
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  53 Water Street, Vancouver, BCMy thrifty husband loved this boisterous Italian restaurant. He loves trains, and the Factory has a real antique trolley car in the middle of the restaurant. He insisted we wait until a table opened up inside the trolley, car, and while that took 45 minutes at this always busy spot, the wait staff were considerate and let us munch on garlic bread while we waited. Once we were seated, we devoured huge portions of spaghetti, meatballs, and bread, all for a very reasonable price. This restaurant is not for everyone, but if you have kids or are young at heart, the Spaghetti Factory is worth the wait. The food is standard Italian fare - meatballs, pastas and salads. Expect to pay -12 a person.

properties.name: Orcas Island
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 Orcas Island, WAWe took the ferry from San Juan Island to Orcas Island for free as walk-ons and rented a car near the ferry dock to drive around the island. The ferry ride itself makes an inexpensive day trip as you cruise through the islands. Bring your camera. Drive up to Mt. Constitution, as the views are spectacular. We could see the entire San Juan Island system for 360 degrees, as well as mainland Washington state. There are also some beautiful places to stop along the road up to the mountain, with a sparkling lake and a short hiking path back into a waterfall. This is a great island for outdoor activities from sea kayaking to hiking. Don\'t try to bike this island unless you don\'t mind getting knee replacements - it\'s extremely hilly.

properties.name: Pagliacci's Italian
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 1011 Broad Street, Victoria, BCWe ate here our first night in Victoria, not knowing much about the place except that it had a line out the door so it must be good. We were not disappointed! This is an extremely lively Italian restaurant, with tables squeezed close and conversations begging to be eavesdropped. If you\'re looking for a romantic Italian dining experience, go elsewhere. Pagliacci\'s is all about the food and conversation. The food is unusually good and worth the wait. Expect to pay 0-20.

properties.name: Parliament - Mixing with Politics
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   501 Belleville Street, Victoria, BCBeautiful architecture, dazzling when lit up at night, and long grassy expanses begging you to spread a blanket and picnic as the people parade goes by. You can also freely explore the corridors of government, peeking into Parliament\'s chambers when not in session, gazing up at the dazzling dome, and reading the words of wisdom in the stained glass windows. This is one of Victoria\'s best free attractions.

properties.name: Prospect Point Lighthouse
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  5700 Stanley Park Drive, Vancouver, BCA great location to rest after a few hours of walking the Stanley Park seawall promenade. Here we took enough photos to fill a couple photo albums, the views were that breathtaking! From here, you can see the Lions Gate Bridge arching over the water to the southern part of the city. Break out a picnic lunch and inhale the sea air (while indulging your husband in yet another photo!)

properties.name: Robson Street - Overrated Shopping District
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  900 W Robson St, Vancouver, BCIf you\'re looking for a unique Vancouver experience and original shops, stay away from Robson Street. I love shopping, but this street is lined with all the same stores I can find back in Wisconsin, and the sidewalks are more crowded than New York City. For unique souvenirs, head to Chinatown, Granville Island or the Punjabi Market.

properties.name: Roche Harbor
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   Roche Harbor, WACome to this small community in the early evening for a dinner overlooking the harbor and to watch the ceremonial lowering of the harbor flag. While I found the flag-lowering ceremony slightly hokey, kids will love the marching and shooting of the cannon (cover your ears!). Sunset over the yachts in the harbor is especially picture-worthy.

properties.name: Rose's on Orcas Island
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 382 Prune Alley, Eastsound, WAOn our drive through Orcas Island, we stopped in the town of Eastsound for a bite to eat. Rose\'s hit the spot - casual outdoor seating and a flavorful, inexpensive menu of soups, sandwiches and seafood-inspired dishes. I had a delicate chowder with oysters, which was creamy, soothing and filling. Expect to pay -17 a person.

properties.name: Royal BC Museum
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  675 Belleville Street, Victoria, BCEvery time I\'m in Victoria, I check out this densely packed museum. It never ceases to fascinate me. There\'s something here to engage everyone, from nostalgia clothing and toys, to interactive displays on Victoria\'s frontier history, and giant Victorian street-scapes kids will love poking around. (Even big kids, like my husband!) The First Nations exhibit is extremely tasteful and informative. Skip the museum food and only check out the giant IMAX screen if you\'ve never seen an IMAX movie before or you have the kids along.

properties.name: Sam's Deli
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 805 Government Street, Victoria, BCA very popular lunch spot on "tourist row" in Victoria, so try to avoid the lunch hour. While nothing extraordinary, Sam\'s provides a great value for your money - tasty, healthy, and filling sandwiches. Try to snag a sidewalk table for some people-watching. Expect to pay -9.

properties.name: San Juan Islands
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2     Friday Harbor, San Juan Island, WashingtonSeattle\'s premier weekend escape may be "discovered", but don\'t let the crowds keep you away. The gorgeous vistas are reason enough to make the trek here. The pace of island life and the friendly people will do wonders for your stressed soul. Find a quiet bed and breakfast, bring a good book, and sample the local wine. The town of Friday Harbor makes a good base for exploring the other islands. If you\'re fit, rent a bike and bike around San Juan Island, taking in the ocean vistas and historical sites. You can also try a guided kayaking tour or go whale-watching. Make sure to visit Orcas Island\'s Mt. Constitution for one of the most jaw-dropping vistas I\'ve ever seen. The four main islands are connected by frequent ferries. The Washington State Ferries are crowded and on peak weekends in the summer you may have a long wait if you\'re driving your car. Ditch the car in Anacortes and walk-on to the ferry with your luggage - stress and hassle free! If you\'re really adventerous, take Amtrak from Seattle or Vancouver BC to Mt. Vernon, then take the local bus system out to the ferry terminal in Anacortes. You can also take the ferry as a walk-on from Victoria, BC. We found traveling without a car surprisingly refreshing. Be prepared for the higher cost of living on the islands and consider picnicking for breakfast and lunch to save money for a nice dinner.

properties.name: Scenic Coal Harbour Seawalk
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 1500 Coal Harbour Quay, Vancouver, BCA lovely place to linger and stroll arm-in-arm with your sweetheart. This seawalk links Stanley Park with Canada Place, and boasts breath-taking views of the hills and mountains of North Vancouver, and passes some quiet little harbors. Best in the early morning when the sun is cool and the city is just waking up. Bring coffee and some bagels for breakfast. And best of all, it\'s free!

properties.name: Second Beach
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   8500 Stanley Park Drive, Vancouver, BCThis is the most family friendly of the beaches, with a huge oceanside freshwater pool, and a less-crowded atmosphere than English Bay Beach. Amazing views of the sunset. I prefer this beach or Third Beach to laze the day away over hyper English Bay Beach.

properties.name: Sedate and British Victoria
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2      Victoria, BC, CanadaThe second stop on our honeymoon. Victoria surprised my husband. I have been here many times, and it was a delight to see the city through his eyes. A visit here slows life down and melts away the stress. The museums are engaging, the gardens are exquisite escapes from the crowds (unless you visit the Butchart!), and the local bus drivers are the friendliest we\'ve ever met! As long as you escape the throngs on Government Street, you will come away relaxed and wanting more.

properties.name: Siam Thai Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 512 Fort Street, Victoria, BCMy husband had never tried Thai food, so when we stumbled across this Thai place in Victoria, we had to try it. Scumptous! My husband is now a fan of Thai. While the atmosphere and service are ho-hum, the food is a nice break from Victoria\'s pub and seafood scene. This is also a great value, as you will be served large portions. Two people can easily share one dinner plate. Expect to pay -15.

properties.name: Stanley Park - Urban Oasis!
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2     Stanley Park, Vancouver, BCThe absolute highlight of Vancouver! We spent an entire day here, walking the seawall promenande from the north side of the city and around to the crowded beaches on the south side. Sane people should elect to use the park\'s bus system or rent some bikes to get around, but if you have all day to linger, walking isn\'t too bad. Just make sure you have a picnic packed, as there is no way up to the restaurants on Prospect Point from the promenade. (We ended up surviving on a lunch of granola bars...and if you\'re diabetic or hypoglycemic like we are, this is a very foolish strategy...in our defense the map can be misleading!) Along the way we saw totem poles, a cannon used as a clock, locals enjoying a cricket match, the Vancouver Aquarium, lighthouses, beautiful vistas, exotic boats (one looked like it was an old Chinese trading ship from the 1800s), and locals fishing. Pack your swimming suit and towel to join the locals at the crowded beaches at the end of your walk. This park offers something for everyone.

properties.name: Starfish Glassworks
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  630 Yates Street, Victoria, BCPeek into this fun working gallery of glass. While my husband wasn\'t a fan of the finished glassware on display, I found the various goblets, bowls, and sculptures beautiful and affordable pieces of art. You can watch the artists at work as they practice glassblowing. The gallery overlooks the studio, so you get a birdseye view of the process.

properties.name: Stepho's - worth the wait!
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 1124 Davie Street, Vancouver, BCWe waited a LONG time to get into this restaurant, the line literally strecthing far down the block. We questioned the wisdom of waiting 45 minutes for a seat (they don\'t take reservations). Then we finally had a bite of the scumptious Greek food at this family-run restaurant. Flavorful, intense, and so worth the stabbing hunger pains! So either arrive early, or bring a truckload of patience. Also, ask to be seated inside. We were seated on the skinny patio, which at first seemed atmospheric, until we realized all the staff on break were smoking nearby. For someone from a country where smoking in public places is increasingly being outlawed, an unpleasant experience. Expect to pay 5-20 a person.

properties.name: Storeum - Entertaining History Lesson
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  165A Water Street, Vancouver, BCThis historical theatrical presentation in Gastown was fairly new when we visited Vancouver in 2006. The production takes you through the history of Vancouver, from the First Nations to the growth of a modern city, with an emphasis on the heady days of westward expansion. The audience physically follows the actors from scene to scene as time progresses, and the script is surprisingly well-written. Kids and adults alike will enjoy the interactive story-telling.Just be prepared for the cost - it was C2 when we visited.

properties.name: Sunset Beach
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   1400 Beach Avenue, Vancouver, BCOf all the city beaches in Vancouver, this is my favorite. We strolled the beach in the late evening to catch the gorgeous dance of the sunset across the bay. We also happened across an international fireworks festival and joined with hundreds of locals to watch the show. I fell in love with Vancouver that night, as the water buses performed a ballet on the bay, and the moon rose over the crowds gasping at the lights display, the city lights behind us.

properties.name: The English Inn
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  718 F Street, Port Townsend, WAA charming and cozy Victorian bed and breakfast, run by a quirky couple, one is American and the other is British. The rooms have a theme. We stayed in the room with a nautical flavor. The filling and home-cooked morning brunch is to die for! Overall, a great value and located on a quiet street in Upper Town.

properties.name: The Good Company
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  110 N. Richmond Street, Appleton, WIThis is a fun restaurant set inside an old brick warehouse. The decor can only be described as eclectic, like the attic at a grandparent\'s house with trunks and shelves full of fascinating clothes, toys and memorabilia. Kids will find the decor endlessly fascinating. The food is satisfying and well-prepared. The menu is varied with something for everyone, from Mexican to pasta to burgers. This is a great and inexpensive place to bring the family. The place is packed on weekends, so avoid those times unless you don\'t mind a long wait.

properties.name: The Historic Rose Theatre
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2    235 Taylor Street, Port Townsend, WAThis is a hidden gem in Lower Town, on a side street off the main drag. We caught Pirates of the Caribbean 2 here. As a historic theater that opened in 1908 as a vaudeville and moving picture theater, the Rose warrants a look inside, ideally while catching the latest indie film or blockbuster. Make sure the movie you see is in the main auditorium, as the smaller theater, while pretty, isn\'t nearly as interesting.

properties.name: The Sandbar - Disappointing
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 1535 Johnston Street, Vancouver, BCI read a great review about this restaurant. However, I found the entire dining experience at the Sandbar fell short of expectations. My salmon burger was so dry I had to drink copious amounts of water just to swallow it. The service was slow and indifferent, even though the lunch crowd was sparse. The atmosphere was lacking something memorable. It was sterile - not cozy or hip or even eclectic. I would skip this restaurant and dine instead at the nearby Granville Public Market for much less money and much more atmosphere.

properties.name: The Templeton
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 1087 Granville Street Vancouver, BC CanadaOur first morning in Vancouver we stumbled across this tiny diner a couple blocks from our hotel. It didn\'t look like much at first, just a row of booths, and a counter. However, the hearty breakfast fare and the hardworking and pleasant staff made us regulars for our entire stay! The large portions and low price make this diner a great value. Even my thrifty husband was impressed! The bonus was one particular waitress who ran the entire place by herself on a busy weekday morning, and still managed to remember our names. We will definately be back next time we\'re in town. Go early on weekend mornings when everyone in town packs the place for brunch.

properties.name: The Trumpeter Inn
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2 318 Trumpeter Way, Friday Harbor, WAThis bed and breakfast in Friday Harbor is run by a lovely couple. They offer serene accommodations located in the country roads just outside the main town, surrounded by fields and Llamas, take a soak in the hot tub or nap in the hammock.The owners cook up breakfast in the morning using fresh and flavorful ingredients. They are also extremely helpful, giving us a ride to the bike rental shop and providing us with maps of the island. Expect to pay around 20 a night.

properties.name: Third Beach - Sunseek with the Locals
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   7550 Stanley Park Drive, Vancouver, BCOn a hot, sunny summer day, the locals hit the beach. This beach is the least crowded, great for a relaxing afternoon. Lean against the driftwood with a good book and a tube of sunscreen, lay out a picnic lunch, or wade in the cool waters. This is a great way to experience everyday life in the city. While there are no lifeguards here, the waters are generally pretty calm, just keep an eye on your kids.

properties.name: Thunderbird Park
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2     Thunderbird Park, Victoria, BCThis is an important park in the revival of native carving. Today local artists work on their traditional craft to keep the skill and artistry of their heritage alive. The carving longhouse is not always open, but you can still see the results. Gaze up at the magnificant totems, all carved with specific animals and symbols that have meaning to the family the totem represents. One of Victoria\'s best free sights.

properties.name: Totem Poles
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2    1400 Stanley Park Drive, Vancouver, BCWe stumbled across this cluster of totem poles in Vancouver\'s Stanley Park and stood mesmerized. The craftsmanship is amazing. There are also some displays about the local Coast Salish First Nations. One of the totems was carved by Haida artist Bill Reid, well-known in these parts for his artistry and role in keeping the craft of carving totems alive. For anyone interested in Vancouver\'s native heritage, this is a great way to get up close to some towering totems.

properties.name: Tourist Row
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  Government Street, Victoria, BCAll I can say is - GET OFF THIS STREET! If you are looking for an authentic experience, locals, and good food, head anywhere but here. This street is lined with copycat souvenir shops and hypnotized tourists browsing the shelves for the perfect T-shirt or shot glass. I would quickly stroll this street in the early evening when the day-tripper masses have left to check out a few of the gems, like Roger\'s Chocolates and the Christmas shop. But don\'t let this be all you see of Victoria. What a shame that would be!

properties.name: Vancouver Aquarium
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  Vancouver Aquarium, Stanley Park, Vancouver, BCSeals, dolphins, and giant fish - enough to keep kids of all ages occupied for hours! Just be sure to AVOID WEEKENDS, which we were not smart enough to do. The place was crowded with strollers and running, screaming children. Exactly the clientele that should be there, but for two honeymooners, we would have been wise to avoid Saturday. The exhibits are interesting and well laid-out. Try to catch a dolphin show with the trainers. We especially enjoyed the beluga whales.

properties.name: Vancouver, BC - City with a Heart
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2         Vancouver, British Columbia, CanadaI fell in love with this quintessential Pacific Northwest city. Vancouver is surrounded by beautiful outdoor retreats and extremely conscious of its place within the local environment. Life revolves around the water - hop a water bus to Granville Island or sample some of the day\'s seafood catch. The people are friendly, passionate about food and art, and open to people of various backgrounds. They also love to celebrate and enjoy life. While we were here on our honeymoon, we stumbled across a huge gay pride parade, an international fireworks festival, packed beaches, and a vibrant Indian street market. This is a city of festivals and mingling cultures, so be prepared to meet the local people, expand your horizons, and sample some of the local cusine and coffee while you\'re at it!

properties.name: Victoria's Waterfront - Free Nightlife!
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  750 Government Street, Victoria, BCThe best show in town is free! Cliche, but available on Victoria\'s waterfront and along Government street. We strolled the harbor and listened to a variety of street performers, from folk to country to reggae to the just plain wierd. We also came across a Caribbean percussion group that drew such a crowd, people spilled into the street dancing. With so much to experience in the streets, we never even set foot in a pub!

properties.name: Victorian Seaport of Port Townsend
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  Port Townsend, WAFirst stop on our honeymoon in 2006. An 1800s Victorian seaport, the town is a relaxing getaway for couples and anyone interested in maritine history. We were here during the annual Jazz Festival, when the town is inundated with music lovers of all ages. Stroll the quiet neighborhood streets of Upper Town, where most of the Victorian homes are located, and shop and eat your way along Water Street in Lower Town. The views of the Puget Sound are breathtaking.

properties.name: Waterfront Pizza
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2  951 Water St, Port Townsend, WAFor a tiny hole-in-the-wall restaurant consisting of one table and a counter, the pizza here is delectable. If pizza can be described like chocolate! We adored the pizza, which is sold by the slice, and is an affordable way to dine out. Take your pizza down to the pier for an inexpensive picnic.

properties.name: Willows Beach
properties.description: Posted by Kaytwin2   Esplanade Street, Victoria, BCFar from the tourist crowds, we spent a relaxed evening here, journaling to the sound of lapping waves, strolling the shoreline, and taking in the sunset at Cattle Point. There are piles of driftwood perfect for building forts, and the sea is calm for swimming, Kids will love the playground in the nearby park.
